headline: Pork Carnitas
description: Good things take time, and I promise these pork carnitas are definitely worth the wait.
recipeIngredient: 2 tablespoons kosher salt, plus more as needed
Warmed tortillas and salsas (such as red chile de arbol salsa or roasted green salsa), for serving

recipeInstructions.name: Step 1
recipeInstructions.text: Cut 4 pounds pork shoulder and 1 pound pork leg if using into pieces about 5 inches long and at least 2 inches thick. You don’t have to be too precise — you want larger pieces so they don’t cook quickly and get dry.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 2
recipeInstructions.text: Melt about 1 pound of the lard in a large pot (at least 8 quarts) over medium heat (about 250ºF). Working in 2 to 3 batches so as to not crowd the pot, add the pork shoulder and leg and cook until browned all over, about 8 minutes per batch. Transfer to a baking sheet as each batch is ready.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 3
recipeInstructions.text: Add the remaining 3 pounds lard to the pot. Return the pork shoulder and leg to the pot. When the lard is melted, reduce the heat as needed to maintain a low simmer (between 140°F and 197°F). Cook, stirring occasionally with a wooden spoon, for 2 hours.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 4
recipeInstructions.text: Mix 1 cup water and 2 tablespoons kosher salt together until the salt is mostly dissolved. Add the salt water and 1 pound pork skin if using to the pot and stir to combine. Cook for 30 minutes more.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 5
recipeInstructions.text: Pinch a piece of pork shoulder with tongs; it should have some bounce to it and start to shred a little. (If the pork shoulder shreds easily, transfer a piece to a plate and check to see if it is fork-tender. If it is fork-tender, stop cooking.) Continue to cook until the pork shoulder is fork-tender and the outside is lightly browned and crisp, 30 minutes to 1 1/2 hours more. (If the meat is tender before the outside is browned and crisp, increase the heat to medium high and cook just until the outside is browned. Do not cook for too long or the inside will dry out.)

recipeInstructions.name: Step 6
recipeInstructions.text: Transfer the pork with tongs to a strainer and drain well. Line a baking sheet with paper towels and place the pork on it in a single layer to drain further. If using pork leg, remove the meat from the leg and discard the bones. Cut the meat and pork shoulder into bite-size pieces. Cut the skin into thin shreds. Taste the meat and skin and season with more kosher salt as needed. Serve in tortillas topped with salsa.

HowtoTip.text: Salt: You can use Mexican sea salt in place of the kosher salt; you will need 1 ounce.Leftover cooking fat and liquid: The leftover lard is very flavorful and can be reused again for carnitas. Strain out any solids while lukewarm and let cool completely. Refrigerate for a few days or freeze for up to 2 months.Storage: Leftover carnitas can be refrigerated in an airtight container for up to 3 days.

name: Pork Carnitas

author.name: Denise Favela
author.description: Denise Favela is a recipe developer, content creator, and ethnographer specializing in Mexican and Mexican American cuisine. She has a keen interest in the history of Mexican gastronomy, regional cuisine, and Mexican immigrant foodways. Denise is currently collaborating with the University of Texas, San Antonio Special Collections library to support fundraising efforts for the digitization of historical Mexican cookbooks.
